quote: Brother John Bates, is not that   the morning which breaks yonder?
I think it be. But we have no   great cause to desire the approach   of the day.
Who goes there?
A friend.
Under what captain serve you?
Under Sir Thomas Erpingham.
I pray you, what thinks he of   our estate?
Even as men wrecked upon a sand,   that look to be washed off the   next tide.
He hath not told his thought to   the king?

No, nor it is not meet he should.   For though I speak it to you, I   think the king is but a man, as   I am. The violet smells to him   as it doth to me, in his   nakedness he appears but a man.   Therefore, his fears, out of   doubt, be of the same relish as   ours are. Yet, no man should   possess him with any appearance   of fear, lest he, by showing it,   should dishearten his army.
He may show what outward courage   he will, but I believe, as cold   a night as 'tis, he could wish   himself in Thames up to the neck.
Methinks I could not die anywhere   so contented as in the king's   company, his cause being just and   his quarrel honorable.
That's more than we know.
Aye, or more than we should seek   after. If his cause be wrong,   our obedience to the king wipes   the crime of it out of us.

But if the cause be not good, the   king himself hath a heavy   reckoning to make when all those   legs and arms and heads chopped   off in a battle shall join   together at the latter day and   cry all "We died at such a place"   -- some swearing, some crying for   a surgeon, some upon their wives   left poor behind them. I am   afeared there are few die well   that die in a battle.
The king is not bound to answer   the particular endings of his   soldiers, the father of his son,   nor the master of his servant.
Delightful... you're getting   better and better, Data...
Freeze program.
Thank you, sir. I plan to study   the performances of Olivier,   Branagh, Shapiro, Kullnark...
Data, you are here to learn about   the human condition... and there's   no better way than embracing   Shakespeare... but you must   discover it through your own   performance, not by imitating...
Riker to Picard...
Yes, Number One.
Sensors are picking up an   unidentified craft in the Neutral   Zone... It's heading toward   Federation space...
On our way... Picard out. We'll   get to the next act later, Data...   computer, end program.
It is interesting that a king   could pass as a commoner, but why   should he wish to? If he is   the leader... should he not be   leading... ?
But listen to what Shakespeare   is telling you about the man,   Data... a king who has a true   feeling for his soldiers must   share their fears on the day of   battle.
Sir, will I be able to schedule   a performance for the crew in   the near future?
Let's... not rush it, shall we... ?
Outpost Sierra Six confirms our   readings, sir. They identify it   as a Romulan scout ship... bearing   two-seven-zero mark one-four.
A scout ship? Curious. What   would bring a scout ship into the   Neutral Zone?
Shall we transmit a warning to   withdraw, sir... ?
Open hailing frequencies.
Aye, sir.    (stops and looks up in     surprise)   Captain, the Romulan is hailing   us.
Visual... ?
Not within range yet...
Open channel...
Federation ship... do you read...   I require urgent assistance...
This is Captain Jean-Luc Picard   of the...
Federation ship... please help   me... requesting asylum... under   pursuit...
Pursuit... ?
Visual contact. On screen,   Captain...
Red Alert. Open a channel to   the warship.
Come to intercept course. Keep   us out of the Neutral Zone.
Channel is open.
When will the scout cross into   Federation territory?
Forty-one seconds...
Romulan warbird, you have crossed   into the Neutral Zone, and are   engaged in hostile action.   Explain yourself and your intent.
No reply, sir.
Hail the scout.
Responding.
On screen.
Please, you must help me...
We are moving to intercept...   maintain your course and power...
Scout ship is severely damaged,   Captain. Engines inoperative,   shields down.
Position?
Coordinates one-four-zero by   two-zero-five.
Federation space.
Bring us to within five kilometers   of the scout. Mister La Forge,   prepare to extend our shields   around that ship.
Captain, at that range, the   shields won't be able to take much   punishment.
Five kilometers, Commander.
All stop.
Extend shields.
Shields in place... we've got the   scout ship, Captain...
Weapons on the warbird are fully   powered, sir.
Lock phasers...
Open a channel.
Ready.
Romulan warbird, you are now in   Federation territory... if you   do not immediately withdraw...
No argument?
Warbird has re-entered the Neutral   Zone, Captain. Heading for   Romulan territory.       Cowards.
Massive power failure on the scout   ship, sir. All systems are going   off-line.       Including life-support.
Transporter Room Two, prepare to   beam the occupant of the Romulan   ship aboard.
(indicating he should     follow)   Mister Worf.
Data, lock onto the scout ship   and take it in tow... cancel Red   Alert.
Energize.
I must see your captain   immediately.
We'll take you to Sickbay, after   that...
This cannot wait. I have   information vital to your   survival.

Captain's log, Stardate 43462.5.   We have beamed aboard an apparent   Romulan defector. He claims to   be a low ranking logistics officer   with extraordinary information   about a new secret offensive.
The humiliating defeat at the   Battle of Cheron has not been   forgotten. The new leaders have   vowed to discard the treaty and   claim the Neutral Zone. Nelvana   Three is only the first step.
And you're saying a whole base   is already established there... ?
In forty-eight hours, the reactor   core will be on line.
The Federation sensors that   monitor the Neutral Zone just...   missed it... ?
It would seem so.
Unlikely.
In two days, you will have a fleet   of Romulan warbirds... within   striking distance of fifteen   Federation sectors...
The Federation will not permit   it...
Then it is war we're talking   about, isn't it?       Destroy the base now and the   threat is over.
I'm sure you're tired from your   ordeal... and could use some   medical attention. Mister Worf,   accompany Sublieutenant Setal to   sickbay. We'll arrange for your   quarters.
No doubt you will wish to question   me further.
No doubt.
He tells a hell of a story.
You don't believe it...
The empire knows we'd never allow   them to maintain a base within   the Neutral Zone.
Commander, it would not be an   atypical Romulan ploy. In their   long history of war, the Romulans   have rarely attacked first... they   prefer to test their enemy's   resolve.
And how many times in their   history has there been a Romulan   defector?
(beat, checking his     files)   Never, sir.
Because loyalty is fundamental   to their culture.
You really think he's a spy,   Commander?
I think he's been planted to draw   us into the Neutral Zone... we'd   look like the aggressors...
... and the Romulans would have   a legitimate excuse to respond   with force.
Exactly.
That would also not be an atypical   Romulan ploy, sir.
It is always a chess game with   them, isn't it?
Well at least he's given us the   chance to get a look at some   Romulan technology.
Mister La Forge, you will head   the away team over to the scout.       Commander, you and Counselor Troi   will conduct Setal's   interrogation.
Permission to observe the   interrogation, sir...

No, I need you with me on the   bridge, Data... there's much to   be done.       We have less than forty-eight   hours to prevent a war... or   perhaps start one. That depends   on establishing the truth of...
I set the auto-destruct sequencer   before I left the ship.
Why?
Wouldn't you? To prevent your   ship from being captured?
Excuse me for being a little   confused, Setal, but I thought   you were defecting...

I am not a traitor.       All you can see is the opportunity   to exploit me. The Federation   credo, exploitation. You couldn't   get aboard my ship fast enough   -- strip it down, "what secrets   might it reveal that we can   use... ?" You are a short sighted   people... can't you understand   I came to stop a war.
If you could just hold still for   a moment...
With your metabolism, it will take   a couple of days to heal...
Thank you, Doctor... I am   fortunate that you know something   of Romulan medicine.
I've had a chance to gain some   experience recently.
Ah yes... the incident at   Galorndon Core, our two   officers...
You are aware of a great deal for   a logistics clerk.
It was common knowledge.       I can show you my rating code.
Forged credentials are a simple   matter for a spy.
(eyes never leaving     Riker)   How can you allow Klingon Pahtk   to walk around in a Starfleet   uniform?
You are lucky this is not a   Klingon ship. We know how to deal   with spies...
Remove this tohzah from my   sight...
Your knowledge of Klingon curses   is impressive.
But, as the Romulans might say,   only a Veruul would use such   language in public.
Mister Worf, please see to the   security arrangements for our   guest's stay...
You find something amusing?

Lieutenant Worf, I like him. Or,   to be more accurate, I understand   him. He's a warrior. Proud,   fearless, living only for combat.       Exactly the type who will get us   all killed if we're not careful.
This is the food station... you   can reach me through the   com panel.       Later, there are a few more   questions we'd like to ask you...
Computer, water.
Temperature?
Twelve onkians.
This system is calibrated to the   Celsius metric system.
Any temperature at all. On the   cold side of your system, whatever   that is.
There is no unusual activity in   the Nelvana System...
Isolate and magnify the Nelvana   star system.
Nothing on the sensors, sir.

It is hard to believe what we   cannot see, Data. And yet, with   their cloaking technology, a fleet   of Romulan warships could   conceivably be passing right   before our eyes.       There must be a way we can   neutralize that advantage...
Captain Picard, priority one   message from Starfleet coming   in on secured channel.
In my Ready Room. Delay time,   computer... ?
Two hours, twenty-two minute delay   from time of transmission at   Starfleet Command on Lya Three.
Computer, key access four-one-two   mark eight-zero. Picard. Jean-   Luc. Starfleet priority code   Gamma. Decode.
Begin message.

Captain, we have received an   official protest from the Romulan   Empire demanding the return of   your defector. We are obviously   refusing to comply. I join in   your skepticism, but if it is a   deception, the Romulans are   certainly going all out to make   a good show of it. The   Federation Council has convened   in emergency session.       There's no doubt in my mind this   will eventually fall on your   shoulders, Jean-Luc. You've got   him. You must decide if he's   telling the truth. For now, I   suggest you proceed along the   Neutral Zone border toward a   Federation position proximate to   Nelvana Three.
Picard to Lieutenant Worf. Please   come to my Ready Room.
You've never actually stepped foot   on Nelvana Three.
That's right.
You were a logistics officer   assigned to sector eight-one-five...
Eight-one-four.
Eight-one-four, yes. So your   conclusions about the secret base   are solely based on a few files   you happened to see in a   computer.
Massive files, Commander...   transport schedules, troop   movements... construction   reports...
And where are they?       All these files? Why not bring   the files to prove what you're   saying?
It was not a simple matter of   just taking them... Romulan   security is unmatched...
Yet you managed to get all the   way across the Neutral Zone in   a one man ship... quite an   achievement...
I saw an opportunity... I took   it... by the time they realized   I had the scout ship... it was   too late...
Are all logistics officers taught   to pilot scout ships?
I depended a great deal on the   computer to navigate. I have   rudimentary knowledge, that's   all...
Do you expect anything out of this   for yourself?
The idea of a Romulan pursuing a   noble cause is impossible, I   suppose.
It was only a question.
Do you realize I have given up   my life for this? I can never   go back. Do you think I did this   for wealth, a new home, what?
We're trying to get to the truth   here, Sublieutenant.
You have the truth before you. You   are too blind to see it.       I have seen enough bloodshed for   one lifetime.
So have we all.

Then do as I ask! I know how   difficult it is for you to believe   me. I feel the same suspicions   toward you. But we must look   beyond our long-standing animosity   and work toward the good of both   our people.
Slow playback... display engine   logs and power data of both   vessels...
Now... look what happens at   zero-nine-five-four-three-three   on the clock...

The scout has sustained engine   damage... forcing it to drop to   point-six-one-five impulse   power... for all intents and   purposes he's finished, dead...   the warship should overtake   him... only it doesn't. Point   two-six seconds later, the   warbird slows to precisely   the same speed...
Three times... three speed   fluctuations... the warship   always kept its distance... I   don't think they wanted to catch   up.
And yet they fired at the scout   ship... they could have killed   him...
Not necessarily, Doctor... the   Romulans have the same capability   to direct the impact of their   weapons as we do.
Doctor, is there any possibility   his wound was self-inflicted?
It was a bad burn... I hardly   think...
A possibility...
Captain's log, Stardate 43463.7.   We are holding a position at the   Neutral Zone border proximate to   Nelvana Three.

There are twenty one hours left   before the Romulan base becomes   functional, if our guest is   telling the truth. Counselor   Troi, however, feels Sublieutenant   Setal is being deliberately   deceptive.

The Monitor and the Hood are   headed in your direction though   they will arrive too late to be   of assistance. Warnings have gone   out to all outposts along the   border... as well as several   independent vessels in nearby   sectors.       No one here wants a war, Captain.
But we're prepared to take them   on if that's what they want. All   Federation starships have been   placed on Yellow Alert.
Come.
You wanted to see me, Captain?
Data, prepare a class one probe.   Set sensors for maximum scan.   I want every meter of Nelvana   Three monitored.
I will start my calibrations, sir.
One moment.
Sit down.
Do you require something else from   me, sir?

Yes. Your clarity of thought,   your objectivity... as always...       We're very possibly about to go   to war, Data. The repercussions   of what we do during the next   twenty-four hours may be felt   for years to come. I'd like you   to keep the official record of   these events, so we may give   history the benefit of a   dispassionate view.
I will begin immediately, sir.   Is that all?
How are the crew's spirits?
They are concerned, Captain, of   course. But confident. Can you   not see that yourself?
Unlike King Henry, it's not so   easy for me to disguise myself   and walk among my troops.       That's all, Data.
"Now if these men do not die well,   it will be a black matter for the   King that led them to it."
Why must we waste time playing   this ridiculous game?
I sense there is more here you   wish to tell us, yet you force   yourself to hold back.
I've told you all you need to know   about Nelvana Three.
I am not speaking of the base.
The base is all that matters.
You're lying, Setal.
If you'll go to Nelvana Three,   you will see...
We're not going anywhere til we   get to the truth...
You're a spy, aren't you?
No.
Then prove it. You can start by   telling me something about the   location and strength of the   Romulan fleet...
I don't know it...
You're a logistics officer...
For only one sector...
Who's your commanding officer?
Admiral Alidar Jarok.
The position of Romulan bases   along the Neutral Zone...
I don't know...
In your sector then...
Irrelevant.
Strength of troops under your   admiral's command...
Irrelevant.       Irrelevant.
I agree with you... it's not worth   playing this game.
What a fool I've been. To have   come looking for courage in a lair   of cowards.
Captain Picard, priority message   from security officer, Klingon   vessel Patakt...
Lieutenant Worf, handle this at   security station, deck nine...
Aye, sir...
Sensors are configured for   planetary probe, sir... ready for   launch.
Proceed.
Probe on course. Sensors are   functioning...
Coordinate your analysis with   Mister La Forge... I want your   report with dispatch...
I don't know, Data... my gut tells   me we oughta believe what this   guy is trying to tell us...
Your gut?
It's just a... a feeling, you   know? Instinct, emotions...
It seems to me those qualities   interfere with rational judgment.
You're right. They do sometimes.
Then why not rely strictly on   fact?
You can't always trust the plain   and simple facts... they lie   sometimes...
They can lead to wrong   conclusions, but they cannot lie.
What do you think? Is he a   defector or not?
The facts to date would lead to   an objective conclusion that he   is not.
Somehow I think we're gonna catch   the Romulans with their pants down   on Nelvana Three... Just like he   says.
"With their pants down." A   metaphor, catching them in the   act... because your "gut" tells   you so...

But of course you can't just go   with your gut either. It's a   combination, Data... let me put   it this way... all these feelings   that get in the way of human   judgment... that confuse the hell   out of us... that make us second   guess ourselves. We need them.   We need them to help fill in the   missing pieces... because we   almost never have all the facts.
So a person fills in missing   pieces of the puzzle with his own   personality... resulting in a   conclusion based as much on   instinct and emotion as on fact.
Now you're getting it.
What does one do if he has no   instinct and emotion?
Data... look at this... the facts   just took a left turn...
As the probe went into orbit   around Nelvana Three, it began   to pick up low level subspace   radio emissions...
Could they be naturally occuring?
The patterns are clearly   artificial, Captain...
The signal is so faint our ship   sensors can't read it from this   distance.
Can we decode it?
We've tried. It's probably   Romulan... but we can't be sure.
Cloaked Romulan ships could   produce this effect.
What about the planet surface?

Reading nothing but barren rock.   They might be able to hide a base   from the probe... its capabilities   are limited. The only way we'll   know for sure is if we go and take   a look for ourselves.
That will be all, gentlemen.
I take it you've never seen a   Romulan before.
That would be an incorrect   assumption.
Then why do you invade my privacy?
I am attempting to ascertain what   my guts tell me about you.
You're the android.
I know a host of Romulan   cyberneticists who would love to   be this close to you.
I do not find the concept   particularly appealing.
Nor should you.
I am told by various crewmembers   that this viewport is their   favorite on the ship.
I thought it would bring me   comfort. But these are not my   stars. Even the heavens are   denied to me here.
Synthetic swill...
I don't suppose your food   terminals are capable of preparing   a Romulan ale.
I am afraid they would require the   molecular structure of the beverage   in question. And, as you are no   doubt aware, our knowledge of your   planet is quite limited.
The loss is yours. For I have   visited over a hundred different   worlds and none possessed the   awesome beauty of Romulus.
Am I correct in assuming you   regret your decision to come here?

No, what I did had to be done.       But to never again see the   firefalls of Gath Gal'thong, or   the spires of my home rising above   the Apnex Sea. To be exiled from   your home is a bitter thing.
It does appear unlikely that you   will ever be allowed to return   to your world again.
The cold reaction of an android.
But perhaps we can bring Romulus   to you.
Program complete.
Run program.
After you.
The valley of Chula. I know it   well.
You are free to stay here as long   as you wish.
Turn it off. I no longer live   here.
Cancel program.
This is my home now. My future.
I've sacrificed everything. It   must not be in vain.
Arrange a meeting between myself   and Captain Picard.       Tell him Admiral Jarok wants to   see him.
Captain, we have confirmed that   you are holding Admiral Alidar   Jarok...
He's been identified as the   commander at the massacre of the   Norkan outposts. The council   strongly advises you to consider   Jarok an unreliable source of   information.
Show him in.
Wait outside, Ensign. Have a   seat... Admiral Jarok.
Captain... there is no more   time...
(casual, you do not give     orders here)   Have a seat, Admiral.
I am not convinced you are   telling the truth.
What must I do...
You must convince me.

If I had irrefutable evidence...       ... but you did not bring   irrefutable evidence. You brought   no evidence at all. In fact, this   entire escape stretched your   credibility beyond belief. Now   we hear that you are not even who   you claimed to be.       A Romulan defector is virtually   a contradiction in terms. But   Admiral Jarok crossing the   lines...
I have explained my motives to   your interrogators...
Yes, peace in our galaxy.       Except you are not a man of peace,   Admiral. Your military record,   what we know of it, is clear...
... which is precisely why I chose   an alternate identity here...
... the massacre at the Norkan   Outposts, for example...
Your "massacre" was called the   Norkan Campaign on my world,   Captain. One world's hero is   another world's madman. Perhaps   I am neither one.

On what basis shall I decide,   Admiral? Your good word? Are   you willing to reveal ways to   overpower the Romulan B-type   warbirds we may encounter? Are   you prepared to help us detect   them through their cloaking   shields?
You see my problem, Admiral. You   ask us for faith in circumstances   not only difficult to believe but   compounded by your own lies, and   your own reluctance to tell us   all you know...
I cannot betray my people...

You have already betrayed your   people. You have made your   choices. You are a traitor, sir.   If the bitter taste of it   disagrees with you, I am truly   sorry. But I will not risk the   lives of my crew because you think   you can dance on the edge of the   Neutral Zone. You have crossed   over, Admiral. I suggest you make   yourself comfortable.
Do you have children, Captain   Picard? A family?
No.
Then you have sacrificed too much   for your career.
Yes, this is all very interesting,   but...

There's a moment in a man's life,   Captain, that you cannot know...   when he looks down at the first   smile of his baby girl and he   knows that he must change the   world for her... for all children.   It is for her that I am here.   Not to betray the Romulan Empire,   but to save it.

For months, I tried to persuade   the high command that another war   would destroy the empire. They   grew tired of my arguments, and   finally censored me, sent me off   to command a distant sector. This   was my only recourse. I will   never see my child smile again,   Captain. She will grow up   believing her father was a   traitor. But she will grow up.       If you act, Picard. If we stop   the war before it begins...
I cannot. And will not. Unless   I have your unequivocal   assistance.

Admiral Jarok has provided me with   the strength, location and   tactical plans for the Romulan   fleet.       Mister La Forge, he is prepared   to give you data regarding   engines, weapons and cloaking   systems on the warbird class   starship. But I believe we'll   find his experience as a field   commander more valuable in a   strategic sense than in the   technical areas.
Any edge'll help, Captain.
Don't depend on it. For all we   know, he may still be lying.       We'll find out soon enough.   Number One, set a course for   Nelvana Three.
Second officer's log,   supplemental. We are prepared   to enter the Neutral Zone in   direct violation of the Treaty   of Algeron.
We must presume Romulan warships   are cloaked and monitoring us.   We expect swift and heavy   resistance as we approach Nelvana   Three.
Course plotted and laid in.
All decks showing condition red.
Engineering ready, sir.
Defensive systems standing by.
Engage.
Tactical?
Nothing on sensors.
I don't like it... I would have   expected a greeting party...
Number One, you echo another   noteworthy commander in a similar   circumstance. One of your   countrymen...       George Armstrong Custer when his   Seventh Cavalry arrived at the   Little Big Horn.
May we have better luck.
Approaching Nelvana system.
Engage impulse engines.
Nelvana Three on screen.
Still no sign of them on   sensors...    (beat, trace of     discomfort)   In a way, I'd rather be fighting   my way there... it's too damned   easy.
Prepare to enter standard orbit.
Data?
Scanning the planet. No life   forms. No power sources. No   weapons systems.
No indication of a base at all?
No sir.
The subspace signal the probe   detected? The ionization   disturbances?
I am picking them up, sir... but I   cannot identify the source...   They... seem to be moving in an   orbital path with an eight hundred   kilometer apogee.
Have Jarok brought to the bridge.
It's possible they abandoned the   base after he defected.
There is no scarring on the   planet surface that would denote   heavy construction of any kind.
A cloaking device, perhaps...   something to hide the whole   base...
A cloaking device operating on   the surface would be given away   by visible distortion effects.
Perhaps you'd like to tell us why   we're here, Admiral.
There doesn't seem to be a base.
I don't understand...
Nelvana Three, Admiral... no base,   no weapons, no sign of life at   all.
But I saw the tactical   communiques... records...   timetables for completion... an   entire legion was assigned to the   mission...
Could they have been feeding you   disinformation?
You said you had been censored.   Reassigned four months ago. They   knew of your dissatisfaction...   could this have been a test of   your loyalty?
No... no, that's impossible...
They let you escape with an   arsenal of worthless secrets...   what other explanation is there?
Captain, permission to withdraw   from the Neutral Zone.
Proceed.
Helm a hundred eighty degrees about.    Get us out of here, Geordi...
I hear you, Commander...
Three Romulan warships   uncloaking... coordinates...       They're firing photon torpedoes...
Shields holding...
Damage...
Minor damage in the secondary   hull... power transfer fields may   be pinched off... working on it...
Captain... ?
Not yet, Mister Worf.       This is just a tap on the   shoulder. Or we wouldn't be here   talking about it.
They're hailing us, Captain...
On screen...
Captain Picard, I hardly expected   to see you again so soon. It   seems this time you are the one   who has made an aggressive move   across the Neutral Zone...
Commander Tomalak, as I suspect   you already know, we have   responded to a warning of a   Romulan incursion on Nelvana   Three...
But, Captain, as you can see,   there is no incursion...
There is the matter of an   unidentified subspace radio   emission... and ionization   distubrances...
Ah, you must mean our orbiting   probe... we are studying Nelvana   Three for...       archaeological research...
With a cloaked satellite...
Really, Captain, would you have   us believe this satellite is an   excuse for your aggressive charge   across the Neutral Zone?
Believe whatever you wish,   Tomalak. We will be on our way.
Without even an apology, Captain?
If an apology will do, I will   offer it.
I'm afraid it won't. So I will   save you the humiliation.
Get to it, Tomalak.

You see, Picard, after we dissect   your Enterprise for every precious   bit of information, I plan to   display its broken hull in the   center of the Romulan capitol as   a symbol of our victory. It will   inspire our armies for generations   to come and serve as a warning to   any other traitor who would create   ripples of disloyalty.

All the communiques, the records,   the timetables... they were   fiction, written for my benefit...   it was all a... a test... a test   of my loyalty... and you used me   to lure the Enterprise into the   Neutral Zone.
First, Captain, you will return   the traitor, Jarok... then you   will surrender as prisoners of   war...
Do you seriously expect me to   agree to those terms?
No, Captain Picard, I expect you   won't.       You have thirty seconds to decide.
I do not require one second.
Captain Picard, I urge you.   Surrender. Consider the men and   women you would lead into a lost   cause.
If the cause is just and   honorable, they are prepared to   give their lives. Are you   prepared to die today, Tomalak?
I expected more from you than an   idle threat, Picard.
And so you shall have it. Now,   Mister Worf.
Aye, Captain...
Klingon vessels are armed and   ready, Captain.
What shall it be, Tomalak?
You will still not survive our   assault...
Nor will you survive ours,   Commander. Shall we die   together... ?
I look forward to our next   meeting, Captain.
Romulan disruptors powering down,   Captain.
Mister Worf, extend the   appreciation of the Federation...   and my personal gratitude... to   the Klingons.
Aye, sir.
Take us home, Number One.
I did it... for nothing. My home,   my family. For nothing.
He ingested a Felodesine chip.   He must have brought it with him.   I'm sorry, Captain... there was   no antidote.
A letter to his wife and   daughter.
Sir, he must have known it would   be impossible for us to deliver   this.
Today, perhaps... but if there   are others as courageous as   Admiral Jarok... there is hope   for a day of peace when we can   take his letter home.
